facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1555 of 1973 filed against judgment dated 1st October 1973 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Miscellaneous Petition No. 206 of 1973.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1555 of 1973. From the judgment and Order dated the 1st October 1973 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court Bench at Indore in Miscella

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 4 were candidates in election to Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Mhow constituency in Indore district in March 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondents 1 to 4 were candidates in the election to the Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Mhow companystituency in indore district in March 1972.

facts.text: Respondent No. 4 withdrew his candidature.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 4 , withdrew his candidature and the companytest took place between the appellant and res- pondents 1 to 3.

facts.text: Result of election declared on March 12, 1972 and respondent No. 1 declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the election was declared on March 12, 1972 and respondent No. 1 was declared elected.

facts.text: Appellant presented election petition under section 81 of the Act to Madhya Pradesh High Court on April 25, 1972 challenging election of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: On April 25, 1972 the appellant presented an election petition under section 8 1 of the Act to the Madhya Pradesh High Court challenging the election of respondent No. 1 on various grounds.

facts.text: Election petition numbered Election Petition 11 of 1972 entrusted by Chief Justice Binshambhar Dayal to Vyas J. sometime in July or August 1972.

anchor.surface_text: This election petition, which was numbered Election Petition 11 of 1972, and some other election petitions were entrusted by the then Chief Justice  Binshambhar Dayal CJ.  to Vyas J.

facts.text: Surajbhan J. of Madhya Pradesh High Court retired on February 2, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Surajbhan J. of the Madhya Pradesh High Court retired on February 2, 1971.

facts.text: Surajbhan J. requested to sit and act as judge under article 224A with effect from April 28, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: After obtaining the previous companysent of the President, the Chief Justice of Madhya Pradesh High Court requested Surajbhan J. to sit and act as a judge of that companyrt under article 224A of the Constitution.

facts.text: Last appointment of Surajbhan J. by consent of President under article 224A dated November 23, 1972 for one year or till disposal of election petitions entrusted to him.

anchor.surface_text: His last appointment was by virtue of the companysent of the President issued under article 224A of the Constitution as per numberification dated November 23, 1972.

facts.text: On June 2, 1973 Chief Justice directed Vyas J. to sit on Gwalior Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Vyas J. dealt with the election petition filed by the appellant and some other election petitions entrusted to him till June 1973. On June 2, 1973 the present Chief Justice directed that Vyas J.

facts.text: Vyas J. addressed letter to Chief Justice on June 20, 1973 setting out stage of election petitions.

anchor.surface_text: After Vyas J. was ordered to sit on the Gwalior Bench, he came from Gwalior to Indore for the trial of election petitions assigned to him. On June 20, 1973 Vyas J. addressed a letter to the Chief Justice

facts.text: Chief Justice addressed letter to Vyas J. on July 19, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: A letter was thereafter addressed by the Chief Justice to Vyas J. on July 19, 1973.

facts.text: Vyas J. sent letter dated August 5, 1973 to Chief Justice requesting that E.P. No. 11/72 be heard by someone at Indore.

anchor.surface_text: In reply thereto Vyas J. sent letter dated August 5, 1973 to the Chief Justice. The material part of that letter reads as under Regarding E.P. No. 4/72 Vimal Kumar Vs. Thakur Virendra Singh, E.P. No. 9 /72 Mannalal Vs. Kanhaiyalal Nagori and E.P. No. 11/72 Krishna Gopal Vs. P. C. Sethi,

facts.text: Chief Justice endorsed on Vyas J.'s letter: 'He has to try them.'

anchor.surface_text: On the margin of that letter the Chief Justice made an endorsement He has to try them.

facts.text: Chief Justice passed order on August 20, 1973 directing Election Petition No. 11 of 1972 to be tried by Surajbhan J. at Indore Bench.

anchor.surface_text: On August 20, 1973 the Chief Justice passed the following order In exercise of the powers companyferred under Section 80-A 2  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, 1, Chief 2 09 Justice, direct that Election Petition No. 11 of 1972  Krishna Gopal v. P. C. Sethi shall be tried by the Hon. Shri Justice Surajbhan Grover at the Indore Bench of the Madhya Pradesh High Court.

facts.text: Last hearing before Vyas J. on August 22, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The last date of hearing in the petition before Vyas J. was August 22, 1973 when he made a formal order for filing reply to some interim applications

facts.text: Deputy Registrar sent intimation on August 27, 1973 to appellant's counsel that hearing at Indore on September 10, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: On August 27, 1973 the Deputy Registrar of the High Court sent intimation to the appellants companynsel that the hearing of the election petition filed by the appellant and another election would take place at Indore

facts.text: Application filed on behalf of appellant on September 10, 1973 stating Surajbhan J. has no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1973 an application was filed on behalf of the appellant stating that as his election petition had been allocated to Vyas J. for trial, the same companyld number be withdrawn from. him.

facts.text: Surajbhan J. dismissed application on September 11, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1973 Surajbhan J. passed an order dismissing the above application.

facts.text: Another application filed by appellant on September 13, 1973, dismissed by Surajbhan J. on October 9, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1973 an application was filed by the appellant stating that he had number been heard on his, application about the lack of jurisdiction of Surajbhan J. to decide the, appellants election petition.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under article 226 on September 27, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: in the meantime on September 27, 1973 the appellant filed a petition under article 226 of the Constitution for the issuance of a writ of mandamus directing Surajbhan J.

facts.text: Writ petition dismissed by Division Bench Sen and Soni JJ.

anchor.surface_text: This petition came up for preliminary hearing before a Division Bench  Sen and Soni JJ.  of Madhya Pradesh High Court.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Article 132 on application by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On an application filed by the appellant, the High Court granted a certificate of fitness under Article 132 of the Constitution

facts.text: Supreme Court permitted raising second contention under article 132(3).

anchor.surface_text: We have, however, permitted Mr. Sen under article 132 3  to raise the second companytention also.

facts.text: Issues framed on merits in election petition but no evidence recorded.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that issues have, been framed on merit in this election petition but numberevidence has so far been recorded on those issues.
Whether a person sitting and acting as a judge of the High Court under article 224A of the Constitution can exercise the jurisdiction to try an election petition under section 80A

concepts.interpretation: A retired judge requested under Art. 224A to sit and act has all jurisdiction, powers and privileges of a judge of the High Court and is deemed a judge for those purposes, enabling trial of election petitions under S.80A(2).

issues.text: Whether a person sitting and acting as a judge of the High Court under article 224A of the Constitution can exercise the jurisdiction to try an election petition under section 80A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 hereinafter referred to as the Act

anchor.surface_text: Whether a person sitting and acting as a judge of the High Court under article 224A of the Constitution can exercise the jurisdiction to try an election petition under section 80A

issues.text: whether the Chief Justice of the High Court can after entrusting an election petition to one judge allocate it at his request to another judge

anchor.surface_text: and whether the Chief Justice of the High Court can after entrusting an election petition to one judge allocate it at his request to another judge, are the two main questions

arguments.claim: A person sitting and acting as a judge under Article 224A is not a judge of the High Court for the purpose of section 80A(2) of the Act, so Surajbhan J. has no jurisdiction to try the election petition

anchor.surface_text: Four contentions were advanced on behalf of the appellant at the bearing of the writ petition but we are not concerned with only two of them. The first contention was that a person sitting and acting as a judge of the High Court under article 224A of the Constitution was not a judge of the High Court for the purpose of section 80A (2) of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 224A grants all jurisdiction, powers and privileges of a judge while sitting and acting; 'not otherwise deemed' applies only to other matters; non-obstante clause overrides; avoids dead letter interpretation

arguments.claim: Once an election petition is entrusted to a judge like Vyas J., the Chief Justice has no power under section 80A(2) to reallocate it to another judge

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the appeal Mr. Sen has contended on behalf of the appellant, as was done in the High Court, that a person requested to sit and act as a judge of the High Court under article 224A of the Constitution is not a judge of the High Court for the purpose of section 80A of the Act and, as such, Surajbhan J, has no jurisdiction to try the election petition. It is further argued that, even if it may be assumed that Surajbhan J. is a judge of the High Court for the purpose of section 80A of the Act, the election petition filed by the appellant could not, after it had been entrusted to Vyas J., be allocated by the Cliief Justice to Surajbhan J.

arguments.qualifiers: even if it may be assumed
arguments.court_reasoning: No bar in section 80A; reallocation at request of Vyas J. himself; distinguishes Zikar v. State as inapplicable to single judge cases

arguments.claim: Surajbhan J. has jurisdiction as Vyas J. released the petition and Chief Justice is competent to assign to another judge

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1973 an application was filed on behalf of the appellant stating that as his election petition had been allocated to Vyas J. for trial, the same could not be withdrawn from. him. It was stated that Surajbhan J. had no jurisdiction to try the petition and the same should be tried by Vyas J. On September 11, 1973 Surajbhan J. passed an order dismissing the above application.

arguments.court_reasoning: Endorsed by Supreme Court as no legal infirmity

arguments.claim: Article 224A person has all jurisdiction, powers and privileges of a judge of the High Court while sitting and acting

anchor.surface_text: Article 224A starts with the non-obstante clause and provides that notwithstanding anything contained in Chapter V of Part VI of the Constitution, the Chief Justice of a High Court for any State may at any time, with the previous consent of the President, request any person who has held the office of a Judge of that Court or of any other High Court to sit and act as a Judge of the High Court for that State.

arguments.claim: 'Shall not otherwise be deemed to be a judge' means not for purposes other than jurisdiction, powers, privileges

anchor.surface_text: The words while so sitting, and acting show that the person requested not merely has the Jurisdiction, powers and privileges of a judge of the, High Court, he also sits and acts as a judge of that Court. Question then arises as to what is the significance of the concluding words but shall not otherwise be deemed to be a judge of that Court.

arguments.claim: Article 224A analogous to Article 128 and English Supreme Court of Judicature Act s.8

anchor.surface_text: The language of article 224A, but for the difference in the marginal note, is similar to that employed in article 128 which relates to the attendance of retired judges at the sittings of the Supreme Court Indeed, article 224A was a part of the Constitution as originally framed.

arguments.claim: Difference in language of Art.224 and 224A does not affect conclusion that 224A judge has jurisdiction etc.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen has pointed to the difference in the language of articles 224 and 224A. It is urged that under article 224 a person is appointed by the President as an additional or acting judge of the High Court, while under article 224A the person requested by the Chief Justice is only to sit and act as a judge of the High Court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of a statute will numbermally be rejected. We are, therefore, of the view that a person requested to sit and act as a judge of the High Court under Ar

arguments.court_reasoning: Articles deal with different matters; language of 224A sufficient for jurisdiction

arguments.claim: Accepting petitioner's view would render Article 224A a dead letter
Chief Justice can reallocate at request of assigned judge as no bar in section 80A
Zikar v. State does not apply as it concerns division bench without concurrence, not single judge at own request
arguments.court_reasoning: Inapplicable to single judge requesting relief

arguments.claim: Surajbhan J. has jurisdiction to try the election petition and Chief Justice's order has no infirmity

anchor.surface_text: On September 13, 1973 an application was filed by the appellant stating that he had not been heard on his, application about the lack of jurisdiction of Surajbhan J. to decide the, appellants election petition. ... Surajbhan J. held that he had jurisdiction to hear the election petition and that the order of the Chief Justice directing that it be heard by Surajbhan J. did not suffer from any infirmity.

arguments.claim: Respondents controvert petitioner's contentions and support High Court view

anchor.surface_text: The contentions of Mr. Sen have been controverted by Mr. Setalvad on behalf of respondent No. 1 as well a by learned Additional Solicitor General on behalf of the Union of India and they have canvassed for the correctness of the view taken by the High Court.

holdings.text: A person requested to sit and act as a judge of the High Court under Article 224A is a judge of that Court for the purpose of sub-section 2 of section 80A of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante clause overrides Chapter V Part VI; while sitting and acting has all jurisdiction, powers, privileges of judge; 'not otherwise deemed' applies only to other matters like transfer under Art 222; analogy to Art 128 and English Act; purposive interpretation avoids rendering Art 224A dead letter.

holdings.text: There was no legal infirmity in the order made by the Chief Justice reallocating the election petition to Surajbhan J. at the request of Vyas J.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No bar in s.80A(2) to reallocation upon request by assigned judge himself; distinguishes Zikar v. State as concerning division bench without concurrence, inapplicable to single judge case.

holdings.text: The provisions of sub-section 2 of section 80A are mandatory and only a judge of the High Court assigned by the Chief Justice can exercise the jurisdiction to try election petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of Rub-section  2  are mandatory and a person who is not a judge of the High Court concerned and who has not been assigned for the purpose by the Chief Justice cannot exercise the jurisdiction which is vested in the High Court by sub-section

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.80A(1) vests jurisdiction in High Court; s.80A(2) specifies mandatory procedure via assigned single judge; 'ordinarily' qualifies number of judges, not mandatoriness.

holdings.text: It seems indeed desirable that election petitions should ordinarily, if possible, be entrusted for trial to a permanent judge of the High Court, even though additional or acting judges or those under Art 224A are legally competent if assigned.

anchor.surface_text: All the same, looking to the special facts and circumstances of this case, we are of the opinion that it is fit and proper and in the interest of justice that the election petition filed by the appellant be tried by another learned judge of the High

holdings.reasoning_summary: Desirable policy for permanent judges in interest of justice given special circumstances, though legally competent otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The case of Zikar v. The State 1 , to which reference has been made on behalf of the appellant, can hardly be of any help to him. What was laid down in that case was that the Chief Justice of a High Court has numberpower to withdraw and transfer a case of which a division Bench is properly seized to another Bench without the companycurrence of the former. There is numberhing in that case to indicate that a Chief Justice is powerless to withdraw a case from a judge of the High Court.

precedents.cited_proposition: the Chief Justice of a High Court has no power to withdraw and transfer a case of which a division Bench is properly seized to another Bench without the concurrence of the former

justification_sets.label: Section 80A, Representation of the People Act, 1951 support

anchor.surface_text: All the same, looking to the special facts and circumstances of this case, we are of the opinion that it is fit and proper and in the interest of justice that the election petition filed by the appellant be tried by another learned judge of the High Court who may be assigned for the purpose by the Chief Justice of that Court. It seems indeed desirable that election petitions should ordinarily, if possible, be entrusted for trial to a permanent judge of the High Court, even though we find that additional or acting judges or those requested under article 224A of the Constitution to sit and act as judges of the High Court, if assigned for the purpose by the Chief Justice, are legally competent to hear those matters. We, therefore, set aside the order dated August 10, 1973. The election petition filed by the appellant shall number be heard by a permanent judge who may be assigned for the purpose by the learned Chief Justice.

outcome.relief_summary: Legal contentions repelled but in interest of justice, Chief Justice's order allocating election petition to Surajbhan J. set aside; directed to be tried by a permanent judge assigned by Chief Justice
directions: set aside the order dated August 20, 1973 (noted as August 10, 1973)
election petition filed by the appellant be tried by another learned judge of the High Court who may be assigned for the purpose by the Chief Justice

anchor.surface_text: All the same, looking to the special facts and circumstances of this case, we are of the opinion that it is fit and proper and in the interest of justice that the election petition filed by the appellant be tried by another learned judge of the High Court who may be assigned for the purpose by the Chief Justice of that Court. It seems indeed desirable that election petitions should ordinarily, if possible, be entrusted for trial to a permanent judge of the High Court, even though we find that additional or acting judges or those requested under article 224A of the Constitution to sit and act as judges of the High Court, if assigned for the purpose by the Chief Justice, are legally competent to hear those matters. We, therefore, set aside the order dated August 10, 1973. The election petition filed by the appellant shall number be heard by a permanent judge who may be assigned for the purpose by the learned Chief Justice.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on valid reallocation at request distinguishes Zikar on division bench without request

anchor.surface_text: All the same, looking to the special facts and circumstances of this case, we are of the opinion that it is fit and proper and in the interest of justice that the election petition filed by the appellant be tried by another learned judge of the High Court who may be assigned for the purpose by the Chief Justice of that Court. It seems indeed desirable that election petitions should ordinarily, if possible, be entrusted for trial to a permanent judge of the High Court, even though we find that additional or acting judges or those requested under article 224A of the Constitution to sit and act as judges of the High Court, if assigned for the purpose by the Chief Justice, are legally competent to hear those matters. We, therefore, set aside the order dated August 10, 1973. The election petition filed by the appellant shall number be heard by a permanent judge who may be assigned for the purpose by the learned Chief Justice.

edges.explanation: Resolving the interpretive conflict in the issue requires application of dead letter avoidance principle under harmonious construction.
